awd_titl_txt: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: New Frontiers in Polar Coding: 5G and Beyond
awd_abstract_narration:
Since the first mobile phones became available in the 1980s, four distinct "generations" of wireless networks have been deployed to support reliable transmission of ever-increasing volumes of data to a growing number of users. What makes such reliable transmission of information possible are error-correcting codes, first conceived by Claude Shannon over 60 years ago. Polar coding is a key new error-correction technology introduced in the fifth wireless generation, known as 5G, that is currently being developed and standardized. Thus, soon enough, consumers the world over will all be using polar codes whenever making a phone call or accessing the Internet on a mobile device. Polar codes provably achieve the fundamental limits of communication established by Shannon in 1948, with low encoding and decoding complexity. Nevertheless, numerous challenges must be overcome in order to realize the full potential of polar coding in wireless communications. This project addresses these challenges to facilitate successful deployment of polar codes in 5G systems, while investigating fundamental problems in polar coding that lie beyond the 5G time horizon. These problems include polarization for time-varying channels and polar coding for channels with deletions. The results from this part of the investigation will contribute to the foundations of error-correction coding theory, and will also have an impact on adjacent scientific disciplines that are influenced by the polar-coding paradigm.

The discovery of channel polarization and polar codes is universally recognized as an historic breakthrough in coding theory. For short block lengths, polar codes under cyclic-redundancy-check-aided successive-cancellation list decoding are currently the best known coding scheme for binary-input Gaussian channels. Due to this and other considerations, 3GPP has decided to incorporate polar codes in the 5G wireless communications standard. The overarching goal in this project is to explore new frontiers in polar coding, thereby fundamentally advancing the current state-of-the-art in the field. Part of the research aims for immediately relevance to successful deployment of polar codes in 5G, whereas other parts focus on key theoretical problems in polar coding that lie beyond the 5G time-horizon. The specific objectives in this project are as follows: (1) Attain the gains of cyclic-redundancy-check-aided polar list-decoding with significantly lower complexity; (2) Construct practical universal polar codes that are not channel-dependent and provide near-optimal finite-length performance; (3) Develop code-domain multiple access techniques based on polar codes to enable massive connectivity; (4) Design and evaluate polar coding schemes for extended classes of channels, going well beyond the original memoryless and stationary set-up; (5) Extend the polarization paradigm and design polar codes for channels with deletions; (6) Develop a full-scale efficient, low-latency, and low-power system-on-chip implementation of polar list decoders. This project is a natural outgrowth of extensive and transformative prior work carried out by the investigators in polar coding.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview.  Error-correcting codes are essential for ensuring the reliable transmission of data in wireless communications. Fifth generation wireless technology, known as 5G, incorporates for the first time a powerful coding scheme known as polar codes. Polar codes are the first class of error-correcting codes to  achieve the theoretical limits of reliable communication established by Claude Shannon in 1948, with low encoding and decoding complexity. The results of this project  expand the frontiers of knowledge about polar codes relevant to future releases of 5G technology, while solving fundamental problems that advance the understanding of polar coding for scenarios beyond the realm of 5G.

Intellectual Merit.  The main  ingredients underlying the capacity-achieving potential of polar codes are the combination of recursive encoder design using a ''polarization transformation'' (represented by a matrix or  ''kernel'') and a decoding algorithm based upon ''successive cancellation'' (SC).  For a large class of noisy communication channels, it is known that the polar encoder in effect synthesizes bit transmission channels that appear as perfectly noiseless (''good'') or  completely noisy (''bad''), with increasing codeword length. The SC decoder can efficiently recover information bits serially from the good synthetic channels, achieving the information-theoretic limits of reliable communication.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in  improving polar code design and applicability, including: (1) increasing the ''speed'' of  channel polarization at shorter codeword lengths through better kernel design; (2) efficiently distinguishing the good synthetic channels from the bad ones; (3) expanding the class of noisy channels to which polar coding methods can be extended, such as channels with deletion errors and channels with time-varying characteristics; (4) analyzing polar code structural properties and successive cancellation decoder performance to support improved system design.  We present highlights of progress made in all these areas.

In connection with (1), we proved several results about the scaling exponent of polarization kernels, a property that measures how fast capacity is approached as a function of the codeword length. For the binary erasure channel (BEC), we proved that there exists a family of kernels whose scaling exponents approach the optimal value as the dimension of the kernel increases. We gave an explicit construction of kernels with the smallest known scaling exponent for dimensions up to 64.  For the general class of binary memoryless symmetric channels, we lowered the best known upper bound on the scaling exponent.  We demonstrated for the first time that non-binary kernels can accelerate polarization.  

In connection with (2), we developed several general rules to rank the quality of synthetic bit channels on the BEC.  We also compared existing methods of ranking synthetic channels and proposed new methods that compare synthetic channels more rapidly.  

In connection with (3), we proved a polarization theorem for the binary deletion channel with constant deletion rate.  The proof inspired polar code constructions and efficient decoding algorithms that achieve the capacity of the deletion channel. We also developed a modified channel polarization method for ''non-stationary'' BECs, a model  for channels with time-varying characteristics.

In connection with (4), we developed a deterministic algorithm for computing the complete weight distribution of  codewords in a polar code.  It can be efficiently applied to polar codes of length up to 128. We proved several results about the complexity, latency, and optimality of SC  decoding and several of its variations, including  SC-list decoding, simplified SC decoding, list decoding for large kernels, and serial list Viterbi decoding.  The analyses inspired reduced complexity decoding algorithms for  certain  polar codes and other families of codes. Improved constructions of concatenated polar code architectures that support local-global decoding were developed.  A new method of combining polar codes with higher order modulation was proposed.

Progress was also made in other related areas, including balanced polar codes, locally balanced constrained codes, efficient algorithms for the ''bee identification'' problem, and codes for racetrack memories.

Broader Impact.  Broad impact of this research was achieved by reporting the findings in 17 conference proceedings  papers and 7 journal papers.  The journal papers appear in major venues such as IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Information Theory, and IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications. The conference papers were presented at international forums including IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory, IEEE Information Theory Workshop, and IEEE Globecom. The project involved collaborations with other  researchers at UC San Diego, at other academic institutions  in the U.S., Canada, Israel, and Singapore, and  at NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory.  The project provided training and partial support for two postdoctoral researchers, two graduate students, and an undergraduate researcher. One  postdoctoral researcher is now employed in  industrial wireless research,  and the other is continuing his coding theory research in academia. One graduate student received his Ph.D. and is pursuing  postdoctoral research in coding theory, and the other graduate student is continuing to work towards his Ph.D. degree.
